Course Introduction (1/18)

  • What you should know to be in this class.
  • Overview of the course.
  • Reading: None (first class).

Basics of Modeling and Simulation (1/23, 1/25)

  • Familiarity with basic concepts in M&S
  • In class, we will go over the design and implementation of a simple queuing model.

Overview of the Challenges in M&S (1/30)

  • Dagstuhl report. Four years ago there was a workshop to identify the grand challenges facing the modeling and simulation community. As with any workshop the product has a strong bias towards the research interests of the participants. Even so, the Dagstuhl report covers the bulk of important M&S issues and remains quite relevant three years later. Read through this report and be prepared to discuss it. Yes, it's 75 pages long. I suggest you read the entire report, focusing on portions that interest you the most. They can be the parts you expect to discuss actively in class.
  • New Paradigms And New Challenges. More recently, Paul Davis of the Rand Corporation has ruminated on new paradigms and challenges in modeling and simulation. Paul's focus is primarily in military simulation, but his observations are universally applicable.
  • A couple of additional sites regarding grand challenges in M&S that are of interest: LLNL (here's a pdf of the site for easy printing) and the simguy.

Multi-resolution modeling (2/1)

  • Motivated Metamodels: Synthesis of Cause-Effect Reasoning and Statistical Metamodeling. Paul Davis and James H. Bigelow, RAND corporation.
  • Consistency Maintenance in Multiresolution Simulations. Paul Reynolds, Anand Natrajan, and Sudhir Srinivasan. ACM Transactions on Modeling and Computer Simulation.
  • Exploratory Analysis Enabled by Multiresolution, Multiperspective Modeling. Paul Davis. Winter Simulation Conference 2000.
  • Watch the Charles and Ray Eames video, Powers of Ten 9:00 minutes (1977), or visit the homepage.

An Introduction to Yucca Mountain (2/6)

These materials can be downloaded after logging onto toolkit.

Required Readings

  • Whipple, C. G. 1996. Can nuclear waste be stored safely at yucca mountain? Scientific American 274 (6): 72–79.
  • Craig, P. P. 1999. High-level nuclear waste: the status of yucca mountain. Annual Review of Energy and the Environment 24:461–86.
  • Ewing, R. C., and A. Macfarlane. 2002. Yucca mountain. Science 296 (5568): 659–660.

Optional Readings

  • Carter, L. J., and T. H. Pigford. 2005. Proof of safety at yucca mountain. Science 310 (5747): 447–448. Erratum posted Vol. 310 No. 5751 November 18, 2005.

Composability (2/8)

Required Readings

  • Only chapters 1 and 2 of Paul K. Davis and Robert A. Anderson. Improving the composability of Department of Defense models and simulations. Rand Monograph #101, 2003.
  • Mikel D. Petty and Eric W. Weisel and Roland R. Mielke. Computational Complexity of Selecting Components for Composition. Simulation Interoperability Workshop, Fall, 2003.

Optional Readings

  • Mikel D. Petty and Eric W. Weisel. A Composability Lexicon. Simulation Interoperability Workshop, 2003.
  • Ernest H. Page and Jeffrey M. Opper. Observations on the Complexity of Composable Simulation. Winter Simulation Conference, 1999.

Yucca Mountain: Week Two (2/13)

  • Selections from the Yucca Mountain Science and Engineering Report. U.S. Department of Energy. Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management. Your required reading has been bundled together: link. If you are interested in the entire document, a complete version is available from the Department of Energy Yucca Mountain website: link.
  • Choose one of the process model reports and read chapters one and two of your report. The reports are available from the following link to the U.S. Department of Energy.


Model Uncertainty (2/15)

These materials can be downloaded after logging onto toolkit.

  • Stanley Kaplan and B. John Garrick. On the quantitative definition of risk. Risk Analysis, vol. 1, no. 1, 1981. Read pages 1-12 (Sections 1-5 inclusive).
  • M. Elisabeth Pate-Cornell. Uncertainties in risk analysis: Six levels of treatment. Reliability Engineering and System Safety, vol. 54, pp. 95-111, 1996.

Agent Based Models and Epidemic Disease Spread (2/20, 2/22)

These materials can be downloaded after logging onto toolkit.

Tuesday

  • Stan Franklin and Art Graesser. Is it an agent, or just a program?: A taxonomy for autonomous agents. Proceedings of the Third International Workshop on Agent Theories, Architectures, and Languages, Springer-Verlag, 1996.
  • Volker Grimm, et al. Pattern-oriented modeling of agent-based complex systems: Lessons from ecology. Science, vol 310, November 2005.
  • Ross J. Gore, Paul F. Reynolds Jr., Lingjia Tang, and David C. Brogan. Explanation exploration: Exploring emergent behavior. 21st International Workshop on Principles of Advanced and Distributed Simulation, 2007.
  • Slides used in Tuesday's class can be found here.

Thursday

Required readings

  • Chris L. Barrett, Stephen G. Eubank, and James P. Smith. If Smallpox strikes Portland. Scientific American, pp. 54-61, March 2005.
  • Stephen Eubank. Scalable, efficient epidemiological simulation. Proceedings of the ACM Symposium On Applied Computing, pp. 139-145, 2002.
  • Timothy C. Germann, Kai Kadau, Ira M. Longini, Jr., and Catherine A. Macken. Mitigation strategies for pandemic influenza in the United States. Proceedings of the National Academies of Sciences, vol. 103, no. 15, pp. 5935-5940, 2006.

Optional readings

  • Stephen Eubank, Hasan Guclu, V.S. Anil Kumar, Madhav V. Marathe, Aravind Srinivasan, Zoltan Toroczkai, and Nan Wang. Modelling disease outbreaks in realistic urban social network. Nature, vol. 429, pp. 180-184, 2004.

Public Policy (2/27)

These materials can be downloaded after logging onto toolkit.

  • Uncertainty: A Guide to Dealing with Uncertainty in Quantitative Risk and Policy Analysis. M. Granger Morgan and Max Henrion. Cambridge University Press, 1990. Read the introduction and chapter 3 (pp. 16-46).
  • Models in the Policy Process: Public Decision Making in the Computer Era. Martin Greenberger, Matthew A. Crenson, and Brian L. Crissey. Russell Sage Foundation, 1976. Read chapter 10 (pp. 319-341).

Optional Reading

  • National Research Council. Understanding Risk: Informing Decisions in a Democratic Society (1996). Read the preface and chapter 4 (pp. 97-117).
  • Risk Analysis and Society: An Interdisciplinary Characterization of the Field. Edited by Timothy McDaniels and Mitchell J. Small. Cambridge University Press, 2004. Read the introduction and chapter 6 (pp. 163-212).
  • Naomi Oreskes, Kristin Shrader-Frechette, and Kenneth Belitz. Verification, validation, and confirmation of numerical models in the earth sciences. Science, vol. 263, no. 5147, pp. 641-646, 1994.

Chaotic Systems and Weather Forecasting (3/1, 3/13)

Before Spring Break (3/1)

These materials can be downloaded after logging onto toolkit.

  • The Essence of Chaos. Edward N. Lorenz. University of Washington Press, 1993. Chapter 1.
  • Introduction to Mathematical Modeling Using Discrete Dynamical Systems. Frederick R. Marotto. Thomson Brooks/Cole Press, 2006. Sections 3.2 and 3.5-3.8.

After Spring Break (3/13)

These materials can be downloaded after logging onto toolkit.

  • Tilmann Gneiting and Adrian E. Raftery. Weather forecasting with ensemble methods. Science, vol. 310, pp. 248-249, 2005.
  • T. N. Palmer. The economic value of ensemble forecasts as a tool for risk assessment: From days to decades. Quarterly Journal of the Royal Meteorological Society, vol. 128, no. 581, pp. 747-774, 2002.
  • Joel K. Sivillo, Jon E. Ahlquist, and Zoltan Toth. An ensemble forecasting primer. Weather and Forecasting, December 1997, pp. 809-818.

Parallel and Distributed Simulation (3/15)

  • A respectable survey of parallel and distributed simulation: Vee, Hsu: Parallel Discrete Event Simulation: A Survey
  • An overview of the DoD High Level Architecture Dahmann

Time Management; HLA (3/20 & 3/22)

  • Tuesday, 20th: work on your project descriptions. We'll finish taking about time management in parallel simulations, and we'll cover the overview of the HLA from last time.
  • Thursday: Read these papers on the HLA: HLA_1516_P1, HLA_1516_P4, HLA_1516_P5, HLA_1516_P6, Lutz paper

Finish HLA, start DDDAS (3/27 & 3/29)

  • Tuesday, 27th: Read about data distribution management: DDMPart1, DDMPart2, ayani, Mak approach
  • Thursday, 29th. Begin DDDAS, reading TBD.

DDDAS and COERCE(4/3 & 4/5)

Tuesday: Read these papers about DDDAS:

  • Darema 2000
  • Darema 2004
  • Knight paper

Thursday: Some papers that provide insight into COERCE:

  • Waziruddin 2003
  • Carnahan 2005
  • Reynolds 2006
  • Waziruddin 2004

Qualitative Simulation; begin Human Behavioral Modeling (4/10 & 4/12)

Tuesday: Read these papers about Qualitative Simulation:

  • Kuipers 2001
  • Ingalls 2000
  • Leow-Sehwail 2005

Thursday: More on Qualitative Simulation, and begin Human Behavioral Modeling:

  • Pew and Mavor 1998, executive summary

Human Behavioral Modeling; (4/17 & 4/19)

Tuesday: Human Behavioral Modeling:

  • Ritter: SOAR 2003
  • Harmon 2002
  • Harper 2004
  • Giordano 2004

Thursday: Neural Networks: No class

more Human behavioral Modeling; Neural Networks; (4/24 & 4/26)

Tuesday: Fourth case study: Read papers assigned on toolkit, covering Human Behavioral Representation

Thursday: Neural Networks:

  • Optimization overview
  • Neuro-animator
  • Lunar lander video
  • Truck video
  • Pendulum video
  • Dolphin video
  • Eagle lander video

Response surfaces; (5/1)

Tuesday: Response Surfaces:

  • overview of RSM
  • Hood and Welch
  • use RSM automatically

The next three papers are optional reading:

  • RSM using the frequency domain
  • using Bayesian uncertainity
  • reduce the costs of producing the RSM
